Accessibility And Adobe Seminar In London

02 Sep 2001

Using Adobe products to create accessible\nweb content

Details of a forthcoming event sponsored by the Royal National Institute for\nthe Blind.

When:

\n

Friday 19 October, 3pm-5pm\n

\n

Where:

\n

Theatre, International Students House, 229 Great Portland Street,\nLondon W1, UK. [Link to Map]

\n

Nearest tube:

\n

Gt Portland St, Regent's Park.\n

\n

Who should attend:

\n
    \n
  • policy and purchase decision makers from companies and organisations that provide web-based services to the public;
    • \n
  • representatives from web design agencies;
    • \n
      \n
    • web designers;
      • \n
    • web project managers;
      • \n
    \n
  • equal opportunity officers;
    • \n
  • internet users;
    • \n
  • anyone interested in knowing what Adobe is doing to make its products fully accessible to people with disabilities.
    • \n

There can be few web designers who have no knowledge of Adobe's web\nauthoring products, from Acrobat, to Go Live to Photoshop, and\nmany more. Many of Adobe's customers are concerned with creating web sites\nthat are accessible to everyone, including people with disabilities. In his\npresentation, Joe Combs of Adobe will reveal the steps the company is taking\nto ensure that Adobe products help web designers to create web content that\neveryone can read.

Note that this event also provides excellent networking opportunities for\nanyone interested in the field of accessible web design. The atmosphere is\ninformal and relaxed, and conducted in a manner befitting a Friday\nafternoon. Be sure to bring business cards with you.\n

Key speaker:

\n

Joe Combs, Application Engineer, ePaper Solutions, Adobe\n

\n

Joe is responsible for providing pre-sales technical support and assistance\nfor Adobe customers through the evaluation of client needs. He devotes much\nof his time assessing feasibility and managing projects effectively,\ninfluencing the sales achievement and customers' technical strategy.\n

Session introduced by:

\n

Julie Howell, Campaigns Officer (Internet), RNIB\n

\n

Julie is the officer responsible for RNIB's Campaign for Good Web Design,\nthat promotes the creation of web sites and online services that include\npeople with disabilities. She is author of the RNIB report 'Get the message\nonline: making internet shopping accessible to blind and partially sighted\npeople', helped the UK Government draft their own web design guidelines and\nworked with Tesco.com, to make its service accessible to disabled customers.\n

\n

Cost: UK£15.00 + VAT [£17.63 total at current rate of VAT - Ed]. Registration prior to the event is essential. If you\nwish to attend please send an email to julie.howell@rnib.org.uk containing:\n

\n
    \n
  • your name
    • \n
  • your company's name
    • \n
  • your postal address
    • \n
  • your email address
    • \n

Please let us know if you have any reading or access requirements so that we\ncan ensure that you get the most from this event.\n

\n

This event forms part of a programme of RNIB Campaign for Good Web Design\nSupporters Network events. The events take place in London bi-monthly. For\nmore information contact Julie Howell.\n
